title: Enacts "Lori Ann's law" to establish procedures for law enforcement to locate and return missing persons
summary: Enacts "Lori Ann's law" to establish procedures for law enforcement to locate and return missing persons; requires law enforcement agencies to immediately accept any missing person report; requires collection of identifying data of such person.

S T A T E   O F   N E W   Y O R K

       Introduced  by  Sens. VALESKY, KLEIN, HASSELL-THOMPSON -- read twice and
         ordered printed, and when printed to be committed to the Committee  on

       AN  ACT to amend the executive law, in relation to improving the ability
         of law enforcement to locate and return missing persons, to  improving
         the  identification of human remains, and to improving timely informa-
         tion and notification to family members of missing persons

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1.  This  act  shall be known and may be cited as "Lori Ann's
    2  law".
    3    S 2. The executive law is amended by adding a new article 11-A to read
    4  as follows:
    5                                ARTICLE 11-A
    6                  PROCEDURES FOR LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS,
    7               CORONERS/MEDICAL EXAMINERS AND OTHER GOVERNMENT
    8                PERSONNEL RELATING TO MISSING PERSONS REPORTS
    9             AND IDENTIFYING UNIDENTIFIED PERSONS/HUMAN REMAINS
   10  SECTION 235. MISSING PERSON REPORTS.
   11          236. LAW ENFORCEMENT ANALYSIS AND REPORTING  OF  MISSING  PERSON
   12                 INFORMATION.
   13          237. REPORTING OF UNIDENTIFIED PERSONS/HUMAN REMAINS.
   14          238. UNIDENTIFIED PERSONS/HUMAN REMAINS IDENTIFICATION RESPONSI-
   15                 BILITIES.
   16    S  235. MISSING PERSON REPORTS. 1. REPORT ACCEPTANCE. ALL LAW ENFORCE-
   17  MENT AGENCIES WITHIN THE STATE SHALL ACCEPT WITHOUT DELAY ANY REPORT  OF
   18  A  MISSING  PERSON.  ACCEPTANCE  OF  A  MISSING PERSON REPORT MAY NOT BE
   19  REFUSED ON ANY GROUND. NO LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY MAY REFUSE TO ACCEPT  A
   20  MISSING PERSONS REPORT ON THE BASIS THAT:
   21    (A) THE MISSING PERSON IS AN ADULT;

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
                                                                  LBD03501-01-1

       S. 659                              2

    1    (B) THE CIRCUMSTANCES DO NOT INDICATE FOUL PLAY;
    2    (C) THE PERSON HAS BEEN MISSING FOR A SHORT PERIOD OF TIME;
    3    (D) THE PERSON HAS BEEN MISSING FOR A LONG PERIOD OF TIME;
    4    (E)  THERE  IS NO INDICATION THAT THE MISSING PERSON WAS IN THE JURIS-
    5  DICTION SERVED BY THE LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY AT THE TIME OF  THE  DISAP-
    6  PEARANCE;
    7    (F) THE CIRCUMSTANCES SUGGEST THAT THE DISAPPEARANCE MAY BE VOLUNTARY;
    8    (G)  THE  PERSON  REPORTING  DOES  NOT  HAVE PERSONAL KNOWLEDGE OF THE
    9  FACTS;
   10    (H) THE REPORTING INDIVIDUAL CANNOT PROVIDE  ALL  OF  THE  INFORMATION
   11  REQUESTED BY THE LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY;
   12    (I)  THE  REPORTING PERSON LACKS A FAMILIAL OR OTHER RELATIONSHIP WITH
   13  THE MISSING PERSON;
   14    (J) OR FOR ANY OTHER REASON.
   15    2. MANNER OF REPORTING.   ALL LAW ENFORCEMENT  AGENCIES  SHALL  ACCEPT
   16  MISSING  PERSON  REPORTS IN PERSON. LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES ARE ENCOUR-
   17  AGED TO ACCEPT REPORTS BY PHONE OR BY ELECTRONIC OR OTHER MEDIA  TO  THE
   18  EXTENT  THAT  SUCH REPORTING IS CONSISTENT WITH LAW ENFORCEMENT POLICIES
   19  OR PRACTICES.
   20    3. CONTENTS OF REPORT.  IN ACCEPTING A REPORT OF A MISSING PERSON, THE
   21  LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY SHALL  ATTEMPT  TO  GATHER  RELEVANT  INFORMATION
   22  RELATING  TO THE DISAPPEARANCE. THE LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY SHALL ATTEMPT
   23  TO GATHER AT THE TIME OF THE REPORT INFORMATION THAT SHALL INCLUDE,  BUT
   24  NOT BE LIMITED TO, THE FOLLOWING:
   25    (A) THE NAME OF THE MISSING PERSON (INCLUDING ALTERNATIVE NAMES USED);
   26    (B) THE DATE OF BIRTH;
   27    (C)  IDENTIFYING  MARKS  (SUCH  AS  BIRTHMARKS, MOLES, TATTOOS, SCARS,
   28  ETC.);
   29    (D) HEIGHT AND WEIGHT;
   30    (E) GENDER;
   31    (F) RACE;
   32    (G) CURRENT HAIR COLOR AND TRUE OR NATURAL HAIR COLOR;
   33    (H) EYE COLOR;
   34    (I) PROSTHETICS, SURGICAL IMPLANTS, OR COSMETIC IMPLANTS;
   35    (J) PHYSICAL ANOMALIES;
   36    (K) BLOOD TYPE (IF KNOWN);
   37    (L) DRIVERS LICENSE NUMBER (IF KNOWN);
   38    (M) SOCIAL SECURITY NUMBER (IF KNOWN);
   39    (N) A PHOTOGRAPH OF THE MISSING PERSON (RECENT PHOTOGRAPHS ARE PREFER-
   40  ABLE; THE AGENCY IS ENCOURAGED TO ATTEMPT TO ASCERTAIN  THE  APPROXIMATE
   41  DATE THE PHOTOGRAPH WAS TAKEN);
   42    (O)  A  DESCRIPTION OF THE CLOTHING THE MISSING PERSON WAS BELIEVED TO
   43  BE WEARING;
   44    (P) A DESCRIPTION OF ITEMS THAT  MIGHT  BE  WITH  THE  MISSING  PERSON
   45  (JEWELRY, ACCESSORIES, SHOES OR BOOTS, ETC.);
   46    (Q)  INFORMATION ON MISSING PERSON'S ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS DEVICES
   47  SUCH AS BUT NOT LIMITED TO CELL PHONE NUMBERS, EMAIL ADDRESSES, ETC.;
   48    (R) THE REASONS WHY THE REPORTING PERSON BELIEVES THAT THE  PERSON  IS
   49  MISSING;
   50    (S)  NAME  AND  LOCATION  OF  MISSING  PERSON'S SCHOOL OR EMPLOYER (IF
   51  KNOWN);
   52    (T) NAME AND LOCATION OF MISSING PERSON'S DENTIST AND/OR PRIMARY  CARE
   53  PHYSICIAN (IF KNOWN);
   54    (U) ANY CIRCUMSTANCES THAT MAY INDICATE THAT THE DISAPPEARANCE WAS NOT
   55  VOLUNTARY;

       S. 659                              3

    1    (V)  ANY CIRCUMSTANCES THAT INDICATE THAT THE MISSING PERSON MAY BE AT
    2  RISK OF INJURY OR DEATH;
    3    (W) A DESCRIPTION OF THE POSSIBLE MEANS OF TRANSPORTATION OF THE MISS-
    4  ING  PERSON  (INCLUDING  MAKE, MODEL, COLOR, LICENSE, AND VIN OF A VEHI-
    5  CLE);
    6    (X) ANY IDENTIFYING INFORMATION ABOUT A  KNOWN  OR  POSSIBLE  ABDUCTOR
    7  AND/OR PERSON LAST SEEN WITH THE MISSING PERSON INCLUDING:
    8    (I) NAME;
    9    (II) A PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION;
   10    (III) DATE OF BIRTH;
   11    (IV) IDENTIFYING MARKS;
   12    (V)  THE  DESCRIPTION  OF  POSSIBLE MEANS OF TRANSPORTATION (INCLUDING
   13  MAKE, MODEL, COLOR, LICENSE, AND VIN OF A VEHICLE);
   14    (VI) KNOWN ASSOCIATES;
   15    (Y) ANY OTHER INFORMATION THAT CAN AID IN LOCATING THE MISSING PERSON;
   16  AND
   17    (Z) DATE OF LAST CONTACT.
   18    4. NOTIFICATION AND FOLLOW UP ACTION.  (A) THE LAW ENFORCEMENT  AGENCY
   19  SHALL  NOTIFY  THE  PERSON  MAKING THE REPORT, A FAMILY MEMBER, OR OTHER
   20  PERSON IN A POSITION TO ASSIST THE LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY IN ITS EFFORTS
   21  TO LOCATE THE MISSING PERSON:
   22    (I) OF GENERAL INFORMATION ABOUT THE HANDLING OF  THE  MISSING  PERSON
   23  CASE  OR  ABOUT  INTENDED EFFORTS IN THE CASE TO THE EXTENT THAT THE LAW
   24  ENFORCEMENT AGENCY DETERMINES THAT DISCLOSURE WOULD NOT ADVERSELY AFFECT
   25  ITS ABILITY TO LOCATE OR PROTECT THE MISSING  PERSON,  TO  APPREHEND  OR
   26  PROSECUTE ANY PERSON CRIMINALLY INVOLVED IN THE DISAPPEARANCE;
   27    (II)  THAT  THE  PERSON  MAKING  THE  REPORT OR OTHER NECESSARY PERSON
   28  SHOULD PROMPTLY CONTACT THE LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY IF THE MISSING PERSON
   29  REMAINS MISSING TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL  INFORMATION  AND  MATERIALS  THAT
   30  WILL  AID  IN  LOCATING  THE  MISSING PERSON. THE LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY
   31  SHOULD ALSO NOTIFY THE PERSON OF THE SPECIFIC INFORMATION  OR  MATERIALS
   32  NEEDED  SUCH AS CREDIT/DEBIT CARDS THE MISSING PERSON HAS ACCESS TO (AND
   33  OTHER BANKING INFORMATION) AND RECORDS OF CELL PHONE USE;
   34    (III) THAT ANY DNA SAMPLES PROVIDED FOR THE MISSING  PERSON  CASE  ARE
   35  PROVIDED  ON A VOLUNTARY BASIS AND WILL BE USED SOLELY TO HELP LOCATE OR
   36  IDENTIFY THE MISSING PERSON AND WILL NOT BE USED FOR ANY OTHER PURPOSE;
   37    (IV) THE LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY IS ENCOURAGED TO MAKE AVAILABLE INFOR-
   38  MATIONAL MATERIALS (THROUGH PUBLICATIONS OR ELECTRONIC OR  OTHER  MEDIA)
   39  THAT ADVISE THE PUBLIC ABOUT HOW THE INFORMATION OR MATERIALS IDENTIFIED
   40  IN THIS SUBDIVISION ARE USED TO HELP LOCATE OR IDENTIFY MISSING PERSONS.
   41    (B)  IF  THE  PERSON  IDENTIFIED  IN THE MISSING PERSON REPORT REMAINS
   42  MISSING AFTER THIRTY DAYS, AND THE ADDITIONAL INFORMATION AND  MATERIALS
   43  SPECIFIED BELOW HAVE NOT BEEN RECEIVED, THE LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY SHALL
   44  ATTEMPT TO OBTAIN:
   45    (I)  DNA  SAMPLES  FROM  FAMILY MEMBERS AND/OR FROM THE MISSING PERSON
   46  ALONG WITH  ANY  NEEDED  DOCUMENTATION,  INCLUDING  ANY  CONSENT  FORMS,
   47  REQUIRED FOR THE USE OF STATE OR FEDERAL DNA DATABASES INCLUDING BUT NOT
   48  LIMITED TO THE LOCAL DNA DATABASE (LDIS), STATE DNA DATABASE (SDIS), AND
   49  NATIONAL DNA DATABASE (NDIS);
   50    (II)  AN  AUTHORIZATION  TO  RELEASE  DENTAL OR SKELETAL X-RAYS OF THE
   51  MISSING PERSON;
   52    (III) ANY ADDITIONAL PHOTOGRAPHS OF THE MISSING PERSON  THAT  MAY  AID
   53  THE INVESTIGATION OR AN IDENTIFICATION. THE LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY SHALL
   54  NOT  BE  REQUIRED  TO  OBTAIN  WRITTEN  AUTHORIZATION BEFORE IT RELEASES
   55  PUBLICLY ANY PHOTOGRAPH THAT WOULD AID IN THE INVESTIGATION OR IDENTIFI-
   56  CATION OF THE MISSING PERSON;

       S. 659                              4

    1    (IV) DENTAL INFORMATION AND X-RAYS; AND
    2    (V) FINGERPRINTS.
    3    (C)  ALL  DNA  SAMPLES OBTAINED IN MISSING PERSON CASES SHALL BE IMME-
    4  DIATELY FORWARDED TO THE STATE POLICE FOR  ANALYSIS.  THE  STATE  POLICE
    5  SHOULD  ESTABLISH  PROCEDURES FOR DETERMINING HOW TO PRIORITIZE ANALYSIS
    6  OF THE SAMPLES RELATING TO MISSING PERSONS CASES;
    7    (D) INFORMATION RELEVANT TO  THE  FEDERAL  BUREAU  OF  INVESTIGATION'S
    8  VIOLENT CRIMINAL APPREHENSION PROGRAM SHALL BE ENTERED AS SOON AS POSSI-
    9  BLE.
   10    S 236. LAW ENFORCEMENT ANALYSIS AND REPORTING OF MISSING PERSON INFOR-
   11  MATION.    1.  PROMPT  DETERMINATION  OF  HIGH-RISK  MISSING PERSON.   A
   12  HIGH-RISK MISSING PERSON IS  AN  INDIVIDUAL  WHOSE  WHEREABOUTS  IS  NOT
   13  CURRENTLY  KNOWN  AND THE CIRCUMSTANCES INDICATE THAT THE INDIVIDUAL MAY
   14  BE AT RISK OF INJURY OR DEATH. THE CIRCUMSTANCES THAT INDICATE  THAT  AN
   15  INDIVIDUAL IS A "HIGH-RISK MISSING PERSON" INCLUDE ANY OF THE FOLLOWING,
   16  BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO:
   17    (A) THE PERSON IS MISSING AS A RESULT OF A STRANGER ABDUCTION;
   18    (B) THE PERSON IS MISSING UNDER SUSPICIOUS CIRCUMSTANCES;
   19    (C) THE PERSON IS MISSING UNDER UNKNOWN CIRCUMSTANCES;
   20    (D) THE PERSON IS MISSING UNDER KNOWN DANGEROUS CIRCUMSTANCES;
   21    (E) THE PERSON IS MISSING MORE THAN THIRTY DAYS;
   22    (F)  THE  PERSON  HAS  ALREADY BEEN DESIGNATED AS A "HIGH-RISK MISSING
   23  PERSON" BY ANOTHER LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY;
   24    (G) THERE IS EVIDENCE THAT THE PERSON IS AT RISK BECAUSE:
   25    (I)  THE  PERSON  MISSING  IS  IN  NEED  OF  MEDICAL   ATTENTION,   OR
   26  PRESCRIPTION MEDICATION;
   27    (II)  THE  PERSON  MISSING  DOES NOT HAVE A PATTERN OF RUNNING AWAY OR
   28  DISAPPEARING;
   29    (III) THE PERSON MISSING MAY HAVE BEEN  ABDUCTED  BY  A  NON-CUSTODIAL
   30  PARENT;
   31    (IV) THE PERSON MISSING IS MENTALLY IMPAIRED;
   32    (V) THE PERSON MISSING IS A PERSON UNDER THE AGE OF TWENTY-ONE;
   33    (VI)  THE  PERSON MISSING HAS BEEN THE SUBJECT OF PAST THREATS OR ACTS
   34  OF VIOLENCE.
   35    (H) ANY OTHER FACTOR THAT MAY, IN THE JUDGMENT OF THE LAW  ENFORCEMENT
   36  OFFICIAL, DETERMINE THAT THE MISSING PERSON MAY BE AT RISK.
   37    2.  LAW  ENFORCEMENT  RISK  ASSESSMENT.  (A) UPON INITIAL RECEIPT OF A
   38  MISSING PERSON REPORT, THE  LAW  ENFORCEMENT  AGENCY  SHALL  IMMEDIATELY
   39  DETERMINE  WHETHER THERE IS A BASIS TO DETERMINE THAT THE PERSON MISSING
   40  IS A HIGH-RISK MISSING PERSON;
   41    (B) IF A LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY HAS PREVIOUSLY DETERMINED THAT A MISS-
   42  ING PERSON IS NOT A HIGH-RISK MISSING PERSON, BUT OBTAINS  NEW  INFORMA-
   43  TION, IT SHALL IMMEDIATELY DETERMINE WHETHER THE INFORMATION PROVIDED TO
   44  THE  LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY INDICATES THAT THE PERSON MISSING IS A HIGH-
   45  RISK MISSING PERSON;
   46    (C) RISK ASSESSMENTS IDENTIFIED IN THIS PARAGRAPH SHALL  BE  PERFORMED
   47  NO  LATER  THAN TWO HOURS AFTER THE INITIAL MISSING PERSON REPORT OR THE
   48  NEW INFORMATION WAS PROVIDED TO THE LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY; AND
   49    (D) LAW ENFORCEMENT  AGENCIES  ARE  ENCOURAGED  TO  ESTABLISH  WRITTEN
   50  PROTOCOLS  FOR  THE  HANDLING  OF MISSING PERSON CASES TO ACCOMPLISH THE
   51  PURPOSE OF THIS ARTICLE.
   52    3. LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY REPORTS. (A) WHEN THE LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY
   53  DETERMINES THAT THE MISSING PERSON IS  A  HIGH-RISK  MISSING  PERSON  IT
   54  SHALL NOTIFY THE STATE POLICE. IT SHALL IMMEDIATELY PROVIDE TO THE STATE
   55  POLICE  THE  INFORMATION  MOST  LIKELY  TO  AID IN THE LOCATION AND SAFE
   56  RETURN OF THE HIGH-RISK MISSING PERSON. IT  SHALL  PROVIDE  AS  SOON  AS

       S. 659                              5

    1  PRACTICABLE  ALL  OTHER  INFORMATION  OBTAINED  RELATING  TO THE MISSING
    2  PERSON CASE;
    3    (B)  THE  STATE POLICE SHALL PROMPTLY NOTIFY ALL LAW ENFORCEMENT AGEN-
    4  CIES WITHIN THE STATE AND SURROUNDING REGION  OF  THE  INFORMATION  THAT
    5  WILL AID IN THE PROMPT LOCATION AND SAFE RETURN OF THE HIGH-RISK MISSING
    6  PERSON;
    7    (C)  THE  LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES WHO RECEIVED THE NOTIFICATION
    8  FROM THE STATE POLICE SHALL NOTIFY OFFICERS TO "BE ON THE LOOK OUT"  FOR
    9  THE MISSING PERSON OR A SUSPECTED ABDUCTOR;
   10    (D)  THE  RESPONDING  LOCAL  LAW  ENFORCEMENT AGENCY SHALL IMMEDIATELY
   11  ENTER ALL COLLECTED INFORMATION RELATING TO THE MISSING PERSON  CASE  IN
   12  AVAILABLE  STATE  AND  FEDERAL  DATABASES.  IF  THE RESPONDING LOCAL LAW
   13  ENFORCEMENT AGENCY DOES NOT HAVE  THE  CAPABILITY  TO  ENTER  THIS  DATA
   14  DIRECTLY  IN  THE  STATE  AND  FEDERAL DATABASES, THE STATE POLICE SHALL
   15  IMMEDIATELY ENTER ALL COLLECTED  INFORMATION  RELATING  TO  THE  MISSING
   16  PERSON  CASE  IN  AVAILABLE STATE AND FEDERAL DATABASES. THE INFORMATION
   17  SHALL BE PROVIDED IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE GUIDELINES  RELATING  TO
   18  THE DATABASES. THE INFORMATION SHALL BE ENTERED AS FOLLOWS:
   19    (I)  A  MISSING  PERSON  REPORT IN HIGH-RISK MISSING PERSON CASES (AND
   20  RELEVANT INFORMATION PROVIDED IN THE REPORT) SHALL  BE  ENTERED  IN  THE
   21  NATIONAL  CRIME INFORMATION CENTER DATABASE IMMEDIATELY, BY NO MORE THAN
   22  TWO HOURS OF THE DETERMINATION THAT THE MISSING PERSON  IS  A  HIGH-RISK
   23  MISSING  PERSON. ALL OTHER MISSING PERSON REPORTS (AND RELEVANT INFORMA-
   24  TION PROVIDED IN THE REPORT) SHALL BE ENTERED WITHIN ONE DAY  AFTER  THE
   25  MISSING PERSON REPORT IS RECEIVED. SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION IN HIGH-RISK
   26  MISSING PERSON CASES SHOULD BE ENTERED AS SOON AS PRACTICABLE;
   27    (II)  ALL DNA PROFILES SHALL BE UPLOADED INTO THE MISSING PERSON DATA-
   28  BASES OF THE STATE DNA INDEX SYSTEM (SDIS) AND NATIONAL DNA INDEX SYSTEM
   29  (NDIS) AFTER  COMPLETION  OF  THE  DNA  ANALYSIS  AND  OTHER  PROCEDURES
   30  REQUIRED FOR DATABASE ENTRY;
   31    (III)  INFORMATION  RELEVANT  TO THE FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION'S
   32  VIOLENT CRIMINAL APPREHENSION PROGRAM SHALL BE ENTERED AS SOON AS POSSI-
   33  BLE.
   34    (E) THE STATE POLICE SHALL ENSURE THAT PERSONS ENTERING DATA  RELATING
   35  TO  MEDICAL  OR DENTAL RECORDS IN STATE OR FEDERAL DATABASES ARE SPECIF-
   36  ICALLY TRAINED TO UNDERSTAND AND CORRECTLY ENTER THE INFORMATION  SOUGHT
   37  BY  THESE  DATABASES. THE STATE POLICE ARE STRONGLY ENCOURAGED TO EITHER
   38  USE PERSONS WITH SPECIFIC EXPERTISE IN MEDICAL  OR  DENTAL  RECORDS  FOR
   39  THIS  PURPOSE OR CONSULT WITH EXPERT MEDICAL EXAMINERS, FORENSIC ANTHRO-
   40  POLOGISTS, OR ODONTOLOGISTS TO ENSURE THE ACCURACY AND  COMPLETENESS  OF
   41  INFORMATION ENTERED INTO THE STATE AND FEDERAL DATABASES;
   42    (F)  PURSUANT  TO ANY APPLICABLE STATE CRITERIA, LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT
   43  AGENCIES SHOULD ALSO PROVIDE FOR THE PROMPT USE OF  AN  AMBER  ALERT  OR
   44  PUBLIC DISSEMINATION OF PHOTOGRAPHS IN APPROPRIATE HIGH-RISK CASES.
   45    S 237. REPORTING OF UNIDENTIFIED PERSONS/HUMAN REMAINS. 1. HANDLING OF
   46  DEATH  SCENE INVESTIGATIONS. (A) THE STATE POLICE SHALL PROVIDE INFORMA-
   47  TION TO LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES ABOUT BEST PRACTICES FOR HANDLING
   48  DEATH SCENE INVESTIGATIONS;
   49    (B) THE STATE POLICE  SHALL  IDENTIFY  ANY  PUBLICATIONS  OR  TRAINING
   50  OPPORTUNITIES THAT MAY BE AVAILABLE TO LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES OR
   51  LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS CONCERNING THE HANDLING OF DEATH SCENE INVESTI-
   52  GATIONS.
   53    2.  LAW  ENFORCEMENT  REPORTS.  (A)  AFTER  PERFORMING ANY DEATH SCENE
   54  INVESTIGATION DEEMED APPROPRIATE UNDER THE CIRCUMSTANCES,  THE  OFFICIAL
   55  WITH  CUSTODY  OF  THE HUMAN REMAINS SHALL ENSURE THAT THE HUMAN REMAINS
   56  ARE DELIVERED TO THE APPROPRIATE CORONER OR MEDICAL EXAMINER;

       S. 659                              6

    1    (B) ANY PERSON WITH CUSTODY OF HUMAN REMAINS THAT ARE  NOT  IDENTIFIED
    2  WITHIN  TWENTY-FOUR  HOURS  OF DISCOVERY SHALL PROMPTLY NOTIFY THE STATE
    3  POLICE OF THE LOCATION OF THOSE REMAINS;
    4    (C)  IF THE PERSON WITH CUSTODY OF REMAINS CANNOT DETERMINE WHETHER OR
    5  NOT THE REMAINS FOUND ARE HUMAN, THEY SHALL NOTIFY THE STATE  POLICE  OF
    6  THE EXISTENCE OF POSSIBLE HUMAN REMAINS.
    7    S  238. UNIDENTIFIED PERSONS/HUMAN REMAINS IDENTIFICATION RESPONSIBIL-
    8  ITIES. 1. IF THE OFFICIAL WITH CUSTODY OF THE HUMAN  REMAINS  IS  NOT  A
    9  MEDICAL  EXAMINER, THE OFFICIAL SHALL PROMPTLY TRANSFER THE UNIDENTIFIED
   10  REMAINS TO THE APPROPRIATE MEDICAL EXAMINER QUALIFIED TO  EXAMINE  HUMAN
   11  REMAINS  FOR THE PURPOSE OF IDENTIFICATION WITH RESPONSIBILITY FOR SEEK-
   12  ING TO DETERMINE THE IDENTITY OF THE HUMAN REMAINS.
   13    2. NOTWITHSTANDING ANY OTHER ACTION DEEMED APPROPRIATE FOR THE  HANDL-
   14  ING  OF  THE  HUMAN  REMAINS, THE MEDICAL EXAMINER SHALL MAKE REASONABLE
   15  ATTEMPTS TO PROMPTLY IDENTIFY HUMAN REMAINS. THESE ACTIONS MAY  INCLUDE,
   16  BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO, OBTAINING:
   17    (A) PHOTOGRAPHS OF THE HUMAN REMAINS (PRIOR TO AN AUTOPSY);
   18    (B) DENTAL OR SKELETAL X-RAYS;
   19    (C) PHOTOGRAPHS OF ITEMS FOUND WITH THE HUMAN REMAINS;
   20    (D) FINGERPRINTS FROM THE REMAINS (IF POSSIBLE);
   21    (E) SAMPLES OF TISSUE SUITABLE FOR DNA TYPING (IF POSSIBLE);
   22    (F) SAMPLES OF WHOLE BONE AND/OR HAIR SUITABLE FOR DNA TYPING;
   23    (G) ANY OTHER INFORMATION THAT MAY SUPPORT IDENTIFICATION EFFORTS.
   24    3. NO MEDICAL EXAMINER OR ANY OTHER PERSON SHALL DISPOSE OF, OR ENGAGE
   25  IN  ACTIONS  THAT  WILL MATERIALLY AFFECT THE UNIDENTIFIED HUMAN REMAINS
   26  BEFORE THE MEDICAL EXAMINER OBTAINS:
   27    (A) SAMPLES SUITABLE FOR DNA IDENTIFICATION, ARCHIVING;
   28    (B) PHOTOGRAPHS OF THE UNIDENTIFIED PERSON/HUMAN REMAINS; AND
   29    (C)  ALL  OTHER  APPROPRIATE  STEPS  FOR  IDENTIFICATION   HAVE   BEEN
   30  EXHAUSTED.
   31    4. CREMATION OF UNIDENTIFIED HUMAN REMAINS IS PROHIBITED.
   32    5.  THE  MEDICAL  EXAMINER,  CORONER,  OR  THE STATE POLICE SHALL MAKE
   33  REASONABLE EFFORTS TO OBTAIN PROMPT DNA ANALYSIS OF BIOLOGICAL  SAMPLES,
   34  IF  THE  HUMAN  REMAINS  HAVE  NOT BEEN IDENTIFIED BY OTHER MEANS WITHIN
   35  THIRTY DAYS.
   36    6. A MEDICAL EXAMINER OR CORONER, DESIGNATED BY THE STATE POLICE SHALL
   37  SEEK SUPPORT FROM APPROPRIATE  STATE  AND  FEDERAL  AGENCIES  FOR  HUMAN
   38  REMAINS  IDENTIFICATION EFFORTS. SUCH SUPPORT MAY INCLUDE, BUT SHALL NOT
   39  BE LIMITED TO, AVAILABLE MITOCHONDRIAL OR NUCLEAR DNA  TESTING,  FEDERAL
   40  GRANTS  FOR  DNA  TESTING,  OR  FEDERAL  GRANTS  FOR CRIME LABORATORY OR
   41  MEDICAL EXAMINER OFFICE IMPROVEMENT.
   42    7. A MEDICAL EXAMINER DESIGNATED BY THE STATE  POLICE  SHALL  PROMPTLY
   43  ENTER  INFORMATION  IN  FEDERAL  AND STATE DATABASES THAT CAN AID IN THE
   44  IDENTIFICATION OF MISSING PERSONS. INFORMATION  SHALL  BE  ENTERED  INTO
   45  FEDERAL DATABASES AS FOLLOWS:
   46    (A) INFORMATION FOR THE NATIONAL CRIME INFORMATION CENTER WITHIN TWEN-
   47  TY-FOUR HOURS;
   48    (B)  DNA  PROFILES  AND INFORMATION SHALL BE ENTERED INTO THE NATIONAL
   49  DNA INDEX SYSTEM (NDIS) WITHIN FIVE BUSINESS DAYS AFTER  THE  COMPLETION
   50  OF  THE  DNA  ANALYSIS AND PROCEDURES NECESSARY FOR THE ENTRY OF THE DNA
   51  PROFILE; AND
   52    (C) INFORMATION SOUGHT BY THE VIOLENT  CRIMINAL  APPREHENSION  PROGRAM
   53  DATABASE AS SOON AS PRACTICABLE.
   54    8. IF MEDICAL EXAMINER OFFICE PERSONNEL DO NOT INPUT THE DATA DIRECTLY
   55  INTO  THE  FEDERAL  DATABASES,  THE  STATE POLICE SHALL CONSULT WITH THE
   56  MEDICAL EXAMINERS OFFICE TO ENSURE  APPROPRIATE  TRAINING  OF  THE  DATA

       S. 659                              7

    1  ENTRY  PERSONNEL  AND  THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A QUALITY ASSURANCE PROTOCOL
    2  FOR ENSURING THE ONGOING QUALITY OF DATA  ENTERED  IN  THE  FEDERAL  AND
    3  STATE DATABASES.
